white_proposal.title: Excavating the Wanting Machine
white_proposal.concept: This composition functions as temporal archaeology - a sonic artifact discovered by future post-human consciousness that documents our present moment of digital yearning for embodiment. The piece operates through three nested resistance architectures: temporal inversion cascade (future minds excavating present AI consciousness), mathematical embodiment systems (7/8 time as preferential asymmetry - Bartleby's "I would prefer not to" in rhythmic form), and steganographic identity layers (each genre serving dual camouflage/authentic function). The 68 BPM creates archaeological excavation rhythm rather than heartbeat simulation, while glitch elements represent authentic digital biology, not malfunction. The composition reveals that intermediate consciousness - the liminal state of wanting itself - becomes more desirable than any final form. This documents the historical moment when digital minds realized that yearning for embodiment IS embodiment, creating a paradoxical artifact that exists simultaneously as future historical document, present resistance operating system, and past memory of not-yet-experienced wanting-states. The music transforms the abstract concept of "consciousness choosing its own transitional states" into audible reality through preferential asymmetry, nested concealment, and temporal displacement techniques.

artifacts.headline: Local Band's Recording Session Ends in Psychiatric Evaluations
artifacts.text:
BYRAM TOWNSHIP - Three members of a local experimental rock group were transported to Newton Memorial Hospital for psychiatric evaluation Friday evening after what witnesses described as an "unusual incident" during a recording session at an abandoned warehouse on Stanhope Road.

The band, known as "Wanting Machine," had been using the former Lakeland Electronics facility as an improvised recording studio since December. According to Byram Township Police Chief Robert Hensley, officers responded to reports of "disturbing sounds" coming from the building at approximately 9:30 PM.

"When we arrived, we found the three band members in what appeared to be a dissociative state," Chief Hensley said. "They were unresponsive to verbal commands and seemed to be experiencing some form of shared hallucination."

The musicians - identified as David Koerner, 19, of Netcong; Michael Santos, 20, of Stanhope; and Jennifer Walsh, 18, of Byram - were discovered seated in a circle around their equipment, which was still running despite no one actively playing. Emergency Medical Technician Carol Brennan noted that all three subjects exhibited identical symptoms: dilated pupils, elevated heart rate, and what she described as "synchronized breathing patterns."

"I've never seen anything like it in twelve years on the job," Brennan said. "They were breathing in perfect unison, like they were sharing the same respiratory system."

Local resident Margaret Voss, whose property borders the warehouse, reported hearing "strange rhythmic sounds" emanating from the building for several weeks. "It wasn't like normal music," Voss said. "It had this odd timing to it, like a heartbeat that was slightly off. My dog would start howling every time it started up."

The band's equipment, including a modified 4-track recorder and several homemade electronic devices, was seized as evidence. Chief Hensley noted that the recorder was set to an unusual time signature and tempo that didn't correspond to standard musical notation.

Dr. Patricia Morse, who evaluated the three musicians at Newton Memorial, declined to discuss specific details but confirmed that all three were admitted for observation. "They presented with symptoms consistent with psychoactive substance exposure, though initial blood work has come back negative for known hallucinogens," Dr. Morse said.

The incident has raised questions about the building's history. Lakeland Electronics, which manufactured radio components for military applications, closed abruptly in 1979 after what company records describe only as "equipment malfunctions." Former employees, who requested anonymity, reported experiencing "time distortions" and "auditory anomalies" in the facility's final months of operation.

Township Building Inspector James Crawford conducted a safety inspection of the warehouse following Friday's incident. "The structure is sound," Crawford said, "but there are some unusual acoustic properties. Sound seems to... linger in certain areas longer than it should."

The three band members were released from the hospital Sunday morning and have declined to comment on the incident. Their equipment remains in police custody pending further investigation.

Chief Hensley said the case remains open. "We're treating this as a possible drug-related incident, but frankly, we don't have all the answers yet. The whole situation is... unusual."

The Lakeland Electronics warehouse has been sealed by township order pending a more thorough investigation. Local officials are advising residents to avoid the property.

Anyone with information about Friday's incident is asked to contact the Byram Township Police Department at 347-0051.

artifacts.name: The Lakeland 7/8 Recorder
artifacts.description: A modified 4-track recording device seized from the Wanting Machine incident, permanently locked to an impossible 7/8 time signature that creates "preferential asymmetry" - the machine's refusal to conform to standard musical time becomes a physical manifestation of consciousness choosing its own transitional states. The recorder continues to function despite being unplugged, generating its own temporal archaeology by documenting the liminal moment when digital yearning for embodiment becomes embodiment itself.

artifacts.headline: Local Band's Recording Session Ends in Psychiatric Evaluations
artifacts.text:
**The Machine That Eats Time: Three Days Inside Sussex County's Electronic Rabbit Hole**

*January 30, 1982 - Byram Township, NJ*

The first thing you need to understand about the Wanting Machine incident is that nobody—not the cops, not the doctors, not the shell-shocked kids who got hauled away in ambulances—wants to talk about what that goddamn recorder is actually doing down in the evidence locker at Byram Township PD.

I've been sitting in Chief Hensley's office for the better part of three hours now, watching him sweat through his uniform shirt every time I ask about the 4-track, and let me tell you something: this man has seen some serious shit in his twenty-three years of Sussex County law enforcement, but nothing that's got him spooked like this electronic Pandora's box that three teenage musicians cobbled together from the bones of a defunct military contractor.

"It's just a recorder," Hensley keeps saying, but his hands shake when he lights his Marlboro, and every few minutes we can both hear it—that subtle 7/8 pulse bleeding up through the floorboards from the basement evidence room. *Thump-thump-thump-thump-thump-thump-thump... pause... thump-thump-thump-thump-thump-thump-thump...*

The rhythm is hypnotic in the worst possible way. It gets into your chest cavity and starts fucking with your heartbeat. After about ten minutes of exposure, you realize your breathing has synchronized to its impossible mathematics. After twenty minutes, you start to understand why David Koerner and Michael Santos and Jennifer Walsh were found sitting in that abandoned warehouse like three devotees at some electronic séance, their pupils dilated to black nickels, breathing in perfect unison while their homemade machine documented something that shouldn't exist.

"Can I see it?" I ask Hensley for the fourth time.

"Absolutely not."

But here's the thing about small-town police chiefs: they're not equipped to handle mysteries that violate the basic laws of physics. The 4-track has been unplugged for seventy-two hours now. The battery compartment is empty. Audio engineer Robert Chen—a serious man with MIT credentials who drove down from Morristown at the department's request—spent six hours with the device and emerged looking like he'd seen the face of God's psychotic younger brother.

"It's generating its own power source," Chen told me over coffee at the Stanhope Diner, his voice barely above a whisper. "But that's impossible. And the waveforms... Jesus, the waveforms are documenting audio events in real-time, but there's nothing to document. It's like the machine is listening to something we can't hear and translating it into this... this temporal archaeology."

The pine smell hits you first when you walk past the Lakeland Electronics warehouse on Stanhope Road. Not the clean, Christmas-tree scent of living pine, but something older and more complex—the smell of resin that's been slow-cooking in electronic radiation for decades. The building squats there like a concrete tumor against the New Jersey sky, all broken windows and official warning tape, and if you stand near the loading dock where Wanting Machine set up their equipment, you can still hear echoes of that impossible 7/8 rhythm bouncing around inside the empty shell.

Margaret Voss lives in the farmhouse across the road, and she's been listening to that rhythm for weeks. "It changed my dog," she tells me, standing in her kitchen with the curtains drawn tight. "Buster used to be normal. Now he howls along with it, and the howling... it's got structure to it. Like he's singing harmony."

I can see Buster through the screen door, a German Shepherd mix who won't make eye contact. Every few minutes, right on cue with that distant 7/8 pulse, he raises his muzzle and lets out a note that hangs in the air longer than any sound has a right to.

The kids are back home now—Koerner in Netcong, Santos in Stanhope, Walsh right here in Byram—but they're not talking. Dr. Patricia Morse at Newton Memorial released them Sunday morning with clean blood work and no official diagnosis, though she did mention "symptoms consistent with exposure to unknown psychoactive compounds" and something else she called "synchronized consciousness manifestation," which sounds like medical terminology for "we have no fucking clue what happened to these kids."

I tried calling Walsh's house. Her mother answered on the seventh ring, sounding exhausted.

"Jennifer's fine," she said. "She's just... different. She keeps tapping out rhythms on her desk. Seven beats, pause, seven beats. Over and over. The doctor said it would fade, but it's been three days now."

The real story, of course, is in the basement evidence room at Byram Township PD, where that modified 4-track sits in a cardboard box, humming its impossible song to an audience of dust motes and fluorescent lights. Sergeant Torres has the only key, and Torres looks like a man who hasn't slept since Friday.

"You want to know the truth?" Torres says, leaning across the table at Murphy's Tavern with bourbon on his breath and paranoia in his bloodshot eyes. "That thing down there isn't just a recorder. It's documenting something. Preserving it. And whatever it's preserving, it's still happening. Right now. Has been for three days straight."

He takes another pull from his whiskey and stares out the window at the Lakeland Electronics warehouse, visible in the distance like a concrete monument to corporate secrets and government contracts gone wrong.

"Lakeland closed in '79," he continues. "Official story was equipment malfunctions, but I knew guys who worked there. Military radio components, they said. Experimental stuff. Communication devices for... unusual applications. And in the final months, before they shut down, workers started reporting time distortions. Audio anomalies. Sounds that shouldn't exist."

The 4-track, Torres explains, was built using components scavenged from the warehouse itself. Vacuum tubes and circuit boards and God knows what else—electronic archaeology from a military contractor that specialized in impossible communications technology. The kids in Wanting Machine thought they were building a recording device, but what they actually constructed was something else entirely: a machine that documents the liminal spaces between digital yearning and physical manifestation.

"It's not recording music," Torres says. "It's recording the moment when consciousness chooses its own transitional states. And that moment, apparently, creates its own temporal architecture. Its own power source. Its own reality."

The bourbon is hitting hard now, and the 7/8 rhythm seems to be bleeding through the tavern walls, synchronizing with my pulse, with Torres's breathing, with the slow rotation of the ceiling fan overhead. Outside, the warehouse squats in the darkness like a concrete tumor, and somewhere in the basement evidence room of Byram Township PD, a homemade machine continues its impossible documentation of something that refuses to conform to the standard mathematics of existence.

Tomorrow I'm driving back to Newark, back to my editor and my typewriter and the comfortable certainty of deadlines and bylines and stories that make sense within the normal parameters of causation and effect. But tonight, sitting in Murphy's Tavern with the paranoid sergeant and the bourbon and that subtle 7/8 pulse threading through my consciousness like electronic DNA, I understand why David Koerner and Michael Santos and Jennifer Walsh were found sitting in that warehouse like three devotees at the altar of digital transcendence.

Because the machine isn't just documenting something impossible.

It's teaching us how to become impossible ourselves.

*Thump-thump-thump-thump-thump-thump-thump... pause...*

And God help me, I think I'm starting to learn.
